text: hi Anthony hi everyone
Anthony Fantana here the Internet's
busiest music nerd and it's time for a
review of the new phosphorescent LP
muchacho phosphorescent is the musical
project of singer-songwriter guitar
player Mathew hall he has six following
albums under his belt
all of which sit under the umbrella of
neo folk indie folk all country as well
as Americana the student is a
singer-songwriter through and through
and a lot of the early releases to come
out of this project have more of a sort
of raw tangible sound to the
instrumentation sort of lo-fi and
recording quality but still pretty
mellow and having a lot of emotional
vulnerability and this sense of
mellowness really took over the bands of
music in a huge way especially in 2010
word even showed up in the album title
of the LP here's to taking it easy now
there are a lot of different ways to
play folk music and country music but it
seems that these sweeter and more
pleasant sounds in these genres are what
really sort of speaks to Mathieu
artistically yet he tops a lot of this
heavenly Americana instrumentation with
this warbly voice of his that is very
pleasant as well but also maybe a little
sad now the band's latest LP muchacho is
no less easygoing than much of anything
else they've put out in recent years I
would actually say it's just as
easygoing but it sort of goes about
capturing this vibe in a different way
because glistening reverb kind of
psychedelic and pristine production is
essentially the game changer on muchacho
I wouldn't necessarily call muchacho a
safe record but it is certainly a
friendly record a record that is sure
not to offend much of anybody it's quite
pretty a lot of the time the lead vocals
often have harmonies behind them the
production melts them together and soars
them above the instrumentation and the
instrumentation itself is often very
soft del
like it and and joyous as well as far as
Matthew's lyrical content goes a lot of
what he says seems to kind of revolve
around the same Americana type tropes
evil good the devil love being
downtrodden emotionally instrumentally a
lot of the same sort of culprits show up
on this record bass guitars drums vocals
maybe a little bit of horn a little bit
of string as well as some lap steel very
funky and familiar chord progressions
all over this LP a lot of which seem to
be rooted back in traditional American
music much like the track on this LP
muchachos tune which is a waltz in three
four three four waltz with very bouncy
keyboards echoing out nicely guitars
that wander up and down scales plinky
pianos and though it's all playing at a
tempo it's also distant there's so much
space in between all the instrumentation
it's as if it's all kind of like one
small atom and everything is kind of
rotating very loosely around this one
idea and though Matthews voice doesn't
exactly cut through the reverb in a
really aggressive or or very ear
catching way some of the things he says
can be very poetic very sharp been
up Shepard to Lamb like wave to
the sand and the very uplifting horns
toward the end of this track this song
has a very strong strong sense of
romance to it another track I really dig
on this LP is song for Zula it's one of
the longest songs on this LP and maybe
one of the sharpest and most passionate
as well
there's some great string arrangements
on this track the bass instrumentation
is really reverb din glassy Matthews
vocals have a really striking and
memorable vocal melody to them and not
only that but his lyrics seem to be a
little more audible on this track than
they are on others it's like there are
moments on this LP where he is super
impressed with his own lyricism and he
wants to make sure that everyone hears
it and there are some pretty interesting
lyrics on this track where you singing
about love disfiguring him into
something that he's not recognizing or
another line where he's saying that he
is not going to struggle or stand to be
acknowledged by
his gnarled hands there are a lot of
themes of just loving unconditionally
rejection desperation and maybe I think
a little bit of pride that comes up in
this song in a really interesting way
and another one of my favorite tracks on
this LP is the longest the seven-minute
quotidian beasts I really like that the
band sort of ventures out into a jam on
this track it is a strong Americana
flavor jam there's a real hard groove to
this track despite how pleasant and sort
of reverb the production is on this song
however I will say that this is one of
the moments where I feel like something
a little bit clearer and a little bit
meteor would have been more interesting
it actually sounds more like a one
microphone live recording of the band
just performing in the moment very far
away from the stage the microphone that
is sometimes the CRP production masks
what could have been a good song even
though I do think Matthew is a good
singer capable singer he's a good
lyricist as well when he wants to
display it he doesn't exactly have the
boldest voice or demeanor it also
doesn't help that many of the melodies
that he sings follow very closely in
roots music footsteps maybe Matthew is
sort of hoping longtime fans will follow
phosphorescent up until this point and
sort of fill in the gaps that are being
created with all of this reverb that is
being laid onto this LP because I think
sometimes the reverb on these songs can
hide more than it enhances this combined
with a few tracks on here that are maybe
not so pointed or well written this
album can at times feel sort of say me
say me the song right on right on while
the track does bring a different vibe to
the table it's essentially the album's
rocker average guitar noodling this
stomp strutting bass line to it I like
the minimal percussion to the song is
very simple and I just like that the
band took a kind of stripped-down Velvet
Underground kind of approach to this
song but Matthew doesn't exactly display
the kind of charm and and swagger to
pull this sort of song off I really sort
of sway between being really enthralled
by these songs and being really
underwhelmed by these songs as I sort of
trip through this album from front to
back some tracks on here have a strong
melody and personality to
and others it seems like the very
pleasant production and just soft
instrumentation are the only real
positives I'm feeling a decent two
strong six on this thing if you've given
it a listen
what did you think of it did you love it
did you hate it why what do you think I
should review next and that's it
Anthony Fantana phosphorescent
